qas.question: Which group from the Presbyterian church in rank is above sessions?
What are the area of responsibilities made up of?
In the American and Ireland Presbyterian church, which step is generally skipped?
Which step was recently abolished by Scotland?
The sessions are composed of which types of elders?
What has the Church of America abolished?

plausible_answers.text: Presbyterian Church in America and the Presbyterian Church in Ireland

qas.question: Besides the Church of General Assembly, what others skip the Synod?
Which assembly does the Church of Scotland send the elders to?

context: Above the <b5_0>sessions<b5_0/> exist <a0_0>presbyteries<a0_0/>, which have <a1_0>area responsibilities<a1_0/>. These are composed of <a2_0><b6_0>teaching elders and ruling elders<b6_0/><a2_0/> from each of the constituent congregations. The presbytery sends representatives to a broader regional or national assembly, generally known as the <b9_0>General Assembly<b9_0/>, although an intermediate level of a synod sometimes exists. This congregation / presbytery / synod / general assembly schema is based on the historical structure of the larger Presbyterian churches, such as the Church of Scotland or the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.); some bodies, such as the <b8_0>Presbyterian Church in America and the Presbyterian Church in Ireland<b8_0/>, skip one of the steps between congregation and General Assembly, and usually the step skipped is the <a3_0>Synod<a3_0/>. The Church of Scotland has now abolished <b7_0>the <a4_0>Synod<b7_0/><a4_0/>.[citation needed]
